awd_titl_txt: Conference on "100 Years of Mock Theta Functions; New Directions in Partitions, Modular Forms, and Mock Modular Forms"
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support for the conference "100 Years of Mock Theta Functions: New Directions in Partitions, Modular Forms, and Mock Modular Forms." This conference falls on the 100 year anniversary of Ramanujan's original definition in his deathbed letter to Hardy and will take place at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee on May 18-19 2020. The main theme will be on new developments around the area of partitions, and especially ranks, cranks, and other partition statistics. This conference is oriented at establishing and furthering dialogue on new developments at the boundary of combinatorics and modular forms. This will foster collaboration between researchers working in these fields, and the conference will feature a problem session to delineate and disseminate critical questions, as well as a discussion panel about issues affecting junior and minority researchers. 

In particular, modular forms and mock modular forms have long been essential tools in the study partitions and other combinatorial sequences.  Mock theta functions have led to many results on rank and crank congruences, asymptotics, and inequalities, and conversely, such partition statistics have motivated the development of harmonic Maass forms.  Very recently, Stanton has highlighted several conjectures of his and Garvan's in unpublished notes.  These conjectures seek a combinatorial refinement of the rank and crank statistics. These suggest a deeper structure both on the combinatorial side and in the mock modular form world. These conjectures have the potential to open up new areas of research at the intersection of combinatorics and mock theta functions. Given these cutting-edge questions and the fitting nature of Ramanujan's anniversary of introducing mock theta functions, it is a particularly opportune time to gather experts from these two fields to discuss the future of such questions and related topics, and to involve the next generation of junior researchers in this conversation and collaboration. Further details can be found on the conference website: https://my.vanderbilt.edu/mock/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A conference on mock theta functions, partitions, and their connections was sucessfully held at Vanderbilt University in May 2022. This aimed to discuss problems surrounding recent key conjectures of Stanton on partition ranks and cranks, and to commemorate 100 years since Ramanujan originally wrote to Hardy describing mock theta functions. There was an emphasis on community building betweeen the automorphic and combinatorial worlds. To ensure that many people from diverse backgrounds were invited, the PIs utilized targeted advertising strategies.

There were 29 participants in person, and 24 virtually attending most talks on zoom (a few additional came to selected talks). The results of this conference, slides of talks, notes, and a link to the youtube playlist of videos from the conference were posted publicly. Approximately 2000 views were garnered on the youtube playlist of videos from the conference.

There was also a productive open problem session, with a number of exciting questions. A video of the session was posted to the conference youtube list, and the slides containing the list of questions as well as notes on the session were also added to the conference website. 

Two joint research papers of PI Rolen arose out of discussions with conference participants during and immediately after the conference, whose publications will disseminate research. One of these papers solved an old question of Andrews raised at the open problem session. 

Particular emphasis for funding was placed on junior and women participants, and a career panel discussion was held. Following discssions there, a list of collaborative workshops was created and posted to the conference website.

In addition to regular talks, a lightning talk session took place, which allowed seven more people to give several minute talks, and gave particular opportunity to more junior people to disseminate their research. 

We have commissioned a special issue of the Ramanujan Journal for the conference, which PIs Rolen and Wagner plan to guest edit along with Alladi, Bringmann, and Folsom. We are still taking submissions. Leading mock theta function expert George Andrews has written a keynote article surveying the history of Ramanujan’s mock theta functions over the last 100 years. We are still securing papers to garner enough for a full issue. If insufficient papers are obtained, we will discuss other options with the editor-in-chief, Alladi. 


Last Modified: 06/26/2023
Modified by: Larry G Rolen
